content.div:
A likable enough hodgepodge of science fantasy based on a 100-year-old Edgar Rice Burroughs story. Hunky Canadian Taylor Kitsch plays a Confederate soldier who is transported to Mars, where he must rescue a princess from a marriage of convenience. The result is a disjointed adventure jammed with special effects.

Starring: Taylor Kitsch, Lynn Collins, Willem Dafoe

Rating: Two and a half stars out of five

The blandly-named film John Carter is the tale of a Confederate soldier who goes to Mars, gets involved in a foreign conflict -- ignoring the conventional wisdom that you should never fight a ground war in space -- and falls in love with an alien. (Although, to be fair, he's actually the alien, being an Earthling and all. She's just a Martian in distress who's a bit redder than your usual damsel.)

It comes with all the elements of the classic science-fiction fantasy: bizarre beings, convoluted histories, huge battles and impressive effects. There may not be little green men on Mars, but there are lots of little green screens.

The result is an amiable hodgepodge, a big-budget gamble by the Disney studio on a 100-year-old tale -- it's based on an Edgar Rice Burroughs story written in 1912 -- that isn't a movie as much as a collection of pieces of other movies. The fact that those movies probably got a lot of those pieces from Burroughs in the first place doesn't detract from the feeling of deja vu: a hint of Avatar, a touch of The Lord of the Rings, a helping of Star Wars. Among the creatures that Carter meets on Mars is a giant jelly-like, dog-type creature whose bulldog enthusiasm makes it look like Jabba The Hutt's Shih Tzu.

The film begins in 1881 as Carter -- played by an occasionally colourless but frequently shirtless Taylor Kitsch -- relates his secrets to a character representing Burroughs. This story-within-a-story is a wild adventure that begins a few years earlier when Carter, a Virginian just out of the Confederate Army, is fleeing a band of Apaches when he stumbles into a cave that has a portal to Mars (Burroughs wasn't exactly scientifically minded).

The planet is imagined as a vast desert, in unimpressive 3-D, whose occupants are both human and fantastic. Carter is captured by Tars Tarkas (Willem Dafoe, digitized into a 12-foot beanpole), one of a race of Tharks: giant four-armed beings with tusks, spears and cranky dispositions. The Tharks speak Martian and this part of the film has subtitles (Dafoe's Martian, by the way, is impeccable). Later, Carter is given a potion that turns all the talk into English, another bit of damn-the-torpedoes storytelling.

It turns out that the Tharks, while fierce warriors, are sitting on the sidelines of the big drama on Barsoom, as the natives call the planet (There: you've learned a little Martian). The city of Zodanga, led by the evil Sab Than (Dominic West) wants to conquer the more peaceful Helium where, interestingly, there is not a balloon in sight but where the lovely princess Dejah Thoris (Lynn Collins) is the prize. Sab Than wants to marry the princess, but she'd rather die first -- he's easy on the eyes but hard on the soul -- and Carter comes in handy because a) that shirtless thing we were talking about earlier and b) due to some atmospheric quirk, he can leap hundreds of metres into the air, which gives him a strategic advantage in the damsel-rescuing business.

John Carter was directed by Andrew Stanton, who made the worlds of Finding Nemo and WALL-E so believable, but Barsoom never coalesces into anything other than a collection of computerized creatures and impenetrable mythologies.

Some of it is fun to see, however. The Tharks, for instance, ride galumphing, eight-legged rhino-elephant beasts while the humans get around in gimmicky airships -- whirring gears and levers that clank with mechanical ingenuity -- appropriate to the age when the story was written.

There's also art in the creation of the villains called Therns, shape-shifters who control the planet's politics -- they're the backroom boys of Mars -- and are led by Mark Strong, the go-to bad guy for many such clattering epics.

Unfortunately, the symbolic possibilities of such beings are never investigated: Unlike the best sci-fi, John Carter exists all on the surface. At one stage, the Thern says that to truly demoralize a foe requires spectacle on a grand scale. John Carter provides the spectacle, but the scale is missing.
